newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan's car fleet seen up over 8.0 pct by 2001.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan's car fleet seen up over 8.0 pct by 2001.

text.p: The number of cars on Taiwan's congested roads is expected to rise by more than eight percent by 2001, adding to the country's already serious pollution problems, a Transport Ministry spokesman said on Friday.
He told reporters more than 400,000 additional cars would be clogging the country's streets over roughly the next four years, bringing the total to 5.5 million vehicles from 5.078 million.
The number of motorcycles, the vast majority of them scooters under 150 ccs, is expected to reach 10 million by 2001 from 9.465 million now.
Heavily industrialised Taiwan suffers serious air pollution problems in most cities, though the sources of pollution vary significantly.
In the capital Taipei, vehicle emissions are the primary pollutant, while in southern Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second-largest city, industrial emissions are the main culprit.
Taiwan recently adopted an air-quality warning system that alerts the public to poor air quality in their communities.

In 1991, Taiwan's Environmental Protection Administration introduced a strict emission standard requiring all car and motorcycle emissions to contain less than 4.5 percent of carbon monoxide and 9,000 ppm of hydrocarbons.
The standard forced car owners and makers to install catalytic converters to meet it.
No official statistics about the number of converters used in Taiwan was available, as the device is not a mandatory part, Transport Ministry officials said.
"We don't require car owners to install catalytic converters, but that is a very effective way to meet our emission standard," a ministry official said.
He estimated roughly 85 percent of Taiwan's cars and motorcycles have catalytic converters.
Taiwan uses two main types of converter -- metal-based using platinum, palladium or rhodium and non-metal using pottery and porcelain, ministry officials said.
Taiwan oil monopoly Chinese Petroleum introduced unleaded gasoline in 1990 and will phase out leaded gasoline entirely by 2000, a Chinese Petroleum official said.
